title: Should New York City charge more to ride the ferry?
text:
New York City, along with New Orleans, is a national outlier among the nine ferry systems that each serve more than 1 million passengers a year. | Mary Altaffer/AP Photo Should New York City charge more to ride the ferry?

Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ferry system is the second-most heavily subsidized urban ferry system of its size in the United States.

Those are the findings of the non-partisan Citizens Budget Commission, which last week crunched the numbers at POLITICO’s request. The commission found that only the New Orleans ferry subsidy, at $9.88 a trip, exceeded New York City’s own per-ride subsidy of $9.34.

Story Continued Below

New Orleans and New York City, however, are national outliers among the nine ferry systems that each serve more than 1 million passengers a year.

The Citizens Budget Commission’s numbers, coupled with the city's recent acknowledgment that most of its ferry riders have healthy salaries, point to one of the most frequent questions transit advocates ask about the NYC Ferry: If its riders can afford to pay more, why not charge them more — like the $6.75 riders pay for the express bus — and free up money for other pressing transit needs?

“The key difference between NYC Ferry and the other ferry systems is that the other ferry systems have much higher fares,” said Sean Campion, a senior research associate at the Citizens Budget Commission.

A one-way trip on the NYC Ferry costs $2.75. A ride on the San Francisco Bay Ferry, however, costs between $7.20 and $15.90. A ride on the Golden Gate Ferry costs about $13. The per-trip subsidies for those are a bit more than $4 a ride.

Those ferry services are “certainly a premium service, and the fares to an extent reflect that,” said Ian Griffiths, co-founder of Seamless Bay Area, a transit advocacy group.

One reason that de Blasio’s ferry service has proven so controversial among transit types is that even as he is subsidizing a premium service for people who arguably don't need as much of a subsidy, he has allowed the New York City bus system, on which many more people rely, to languish.

De Blasio launched his ferry service in 2017, as the subways were cratering and the bus system was losing ridership. While riders and transit operators were grappling with a transit crisis of generational proportions, de Blasio cast his ferries as a viable alternative to the governor’s languishing MTA, which runs buses on New York City streets. The mayor even pegged the fare to the price of a subway or bus ride, at $2.75 a trip, to make ferries “affordable to everyday New Yorkers just like our subways and buses.”

“At the very same time as our subways were more and more congested and our roads were more and more congested, this was something that needed to happen for a long time,” said de Blasio in January.

But de Blasio’s rhetoric has had only passing relationship with reality. Ferries may be a boon for some coastal New Yorkers, and they may even make good sense in a city bound by water, but experts agree they carry far too few people to be a real solution to the region’s transit or traffic congestion crises.

In 2017, local MTA buses provided 691 million trips. Most of its riders are low-income New Yorkers of color, just the sort of New Yorkers de Blasio purports to represent. The city projects de Blasio’s ferries will provide 4.6 million trips this year.

"It just seemed the mayor was punting on going after street space," said Benjamin Kabak, the author of the Second Ave. Sagas subway blog and a frequent critic of the ferry system.

De Blasio’s claims that the ferry would correct “inequities,” also seemed far-fetched, except in strictly geographical terms. Thanks to the lack of a uniform fare payment system, riders transferring from ferries to a MTA bus or subway had to pay the $2.75 fare twice, instead of just once as they do when transferring between buses and subways. As many suspected, and a study released last week confirmed, riders of the ferry system are mostly middle-class, white New Yorkers.

“It stings that the ‘Tale of Two Cities’ mayor is the one who rolled [the ferry] out,” said Stephen Smith, a former transportation writer who now works in real estate. “It’s obvious why he did, because it was something he could do without any MTA input at all. But part of being mayor is doing difficult things, like wrangling bureaucracies that don’t want to have anything to do with you.”

As de Blasio was touting the benefits of his ferry service, advocates were asking him to create truly dedicated bus lanes, too — ones that other vehicles couldn’t block with ease. Bus ridership has fallen in recent years, and some advocates fear a death spiral, with falling ridership catalyzing service cuts, which, in turn, could catalyze more riders to abandon the bus.

They saw the bus-ferry funding discussion as "zero sum," said Nick Sifuentes, executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign.

“Here’s a guy who’s put a ton of money into ferries and BQX and has done little to improve road infrastructure for buses,” said Sifuentes, referring to the mayor’s slow-moving light-rail plan. “If the mayor did a little bit of everything — more money for ferries, more money for these projects like BQX, and real money for projects like bus infrastructure, I don’t think anyone would have a problem with that. Or at least, I wouldn’t.”

The de Blasio administration argues that after it launches more ferry lines, it will be able to drive the per-trip subsidy down to between $7 or $8, which would be more in line with the per-trip subsidy on the Long Island Rail Road.

In a statement, City Hall spokesperson Seth Stein said the mayor “is laser focused on getting New Yorkers moving ... any claim otherwise is blind to the facts,” and he’s embracing an “all-of-the-above approach to our transportation system.”

Stein pointed to the mayor’s promise to increase bus speeds 25 percent by the end of 2020 and his recent support for Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s congestion pricing plan.

But last week, even as he launched the city’s most “aggressive” bus lane in history — on 14th Street — the mayor's rhetoric suggested he had no plans to apply that approach anywhere else, anytime soon.

“I said I accept this as a pilot and only as a pilot,” de Blasio said. “And I’m going to see what those results are and it’s going to tell us whether it’s something we want to do other places, and some places might be ripe for it and other places not, obviously. But no, the jury is out.”

Advocates don’t begrudge the mayor a ferry system, exactly, but they do begrudge him sentiments like that.

"To me, at least, the way to fix this is just remove some of the subsidy on the fares," said Kabak. "I don’t think ... the mayor has made a particularly convincing case that we need to be subsidizing this fare to the point it's $2.75 forever."
